questions.title: Question 1 for Class CLIMATE102_191025
questions.main: What are the necessary ingredients for a mid-latitude cyclonic storm to develop into a huge storm system?
questions.answer: Upper-level divergence (usually associated with a shortwave) surface convergence strong horizontal temperature contrast temperature advection.

questions.title: Question 2 for Class CLIMATE102_191025
questions.main: Explain how converging air and diverging air forms at the surface and aloft.
questions.answer: (a) Surface air converges towards the center of a low and diverges from the center of a high.    (b) a region of converging air usually forms on the west side of an upper-level trough and a region of diverging air forms on the east side.

questions.title: Question 3 for Class CLIMATE102_191025
questions.main: In winter cold-front weather is typically more violent than warm-front weather. Why? Explain why this situation is not necessarily true in summer.
questions.answer: The temperature contrast across a wintertime cold front can be much larger than the contrast across a summertime cold front.  The most violent weather occurs when the temperature contrast is larger.

questions.title: Question 4 for Class CLIMATE102_191025
questions.main: Why do some mid-latitude cyclones quickly 'die out' after they become occluded?
questions.answer: The divergence aloft which removes air over the cyclone follows the place where temeprature contrast at the surface is greatest. Afterr the storm occludes the location of greatest temperature contrast shifts away from the center of the cyclone.

questions.title: Question 10 for Class CLIMATE102_191025
questions.main: If upper-level diverging air above a surface area of low pressure exceeds converging air around the surface low will the surface low-pressure area weaken or intensify? Explain.
questions.answer: It will intensify.  When upper-level divergence is stronger than surface convergence surface pressures drop and the low intensifies.
